title: Workers are shocked when they stumble across an unexploded ordnance on a construction site
text:
Construction workers were shocked to find an unexploded ordnance - that looks like a KFC drumstick - buried in a construction site.

The mortar covered in rust was found on Wednesday at Albion Park in the Illawarra at a construction site near the Princes Highway.

The explosive was successfully removed by the Rescue and Bomb Disposal Unit and no one was injured.



The mortar covered in rust was found on Wednesday at Albion Park in the Illawarra at a construction site near the Princess Highway

An image of the mortar was posted on the NSW Police Facebook page, with some saying it resembled a piece of chicken.'

One person said: 'It looks kinda like a KFC drumstick, just with some additional fins at the bottom.'

'I'm so fat! I only saw a drumstick,' another said.

One person joked: 'Mmmm. Deep-fried mortar.'

Mortars are a lightweight, muzzle-loaded weapon that launches explosive shells in high-arching ballistic trajectories.

The explosive was successfully removed by the Rescue and Bomb Disposal Unit and no one was injured (Pictured: Mortar)

During World War II, gun defences were built along the coast of Port Kembla, which is located 21kms from where the mortar was found.

Port Kembla was considered an important industrial centre and it was a major supplier of iron and steel.

The Breakwater Battery, Illowra Battery and Drummond Battery were constructed to provide coastal defence from enemy ships and submarines.

The coastal guns also protected the supply of iron and steel.

During World War II, gun defences were built along the coast of Port Kembla, which is located 21kms from where the mortar was found (pictured: Kembla Fortress)

NSW Police warned people who may stumble across an unexploded ordnance to immediately report it.

'If a suspect item is found, do not touch, disturb or tamper with the item in any way,' the NSW Police said.

'This includes making any attempt to move the item to a 'safe' location.

'Call the police who will arrange for its safe removal.'
